newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore shares may steady after falls.
newsitem.headline: Singapore shares may steady after falls.

text.p: Singapore shares may steady on Friday after a wobbly week that has seen the island's benchmark Straits Times Industrials Index (STII) plumb new four-year lows.

Dealers said there might continue to be pressure on the foreign tranches of some blue chip stocks following news the state-owned Singapore Technologies group had merged the foreign and local share listings of four of its units.
But they said the local tranches of the same stocks, some of which are represented in the 30-share STII, were likely to continue to benefit.

Foreign tranches traditionally hold a premium over local tranches because they can be bought by any investor and tend to be much more volatile. Scrapping the split between the tranches would remove this price differential.
The STII ended 16.39 points up at 1,891.77 on Thursday on a total of 223.2 million shares.
Dealers said the index was likely to range trade until all the interim corporate results were out.
New York's Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 13.71 points overnight to 7,942.03.
